Let's make the CMO be the CMO again. 

Your CMO should be the best storyteller at your company. 

Full stop.

That's my bias, but I'm sticking with it.

The CMO is not the CFO (crazy, right?)

The CMO should be company's best storyteller.

Is the other stuff important? Of course it is. You need metrics. You need reporting. You need data. You need so many things.

But if you don't nail the story to your market, a clear POV, and true differentiation -- none of the other stuff will matter.

And if the CMO can't get the company (internal team) excited and rallied around the company mission, how will you ever be able to get strangers (customers) onboard?

The most valuable asset in any company is its story. And the CMO must be the chief custodian of that story. 

Not a bean counter. 

Not a data wrangler. 

A storyteller.

(my opinion)

A CMO who cannot craft a compelling story - who cannot articulate a clear point of view or highlight what truly sets the company apart - will find that all the data in the world won‚Äôt move the needle.

PS. This is more important now than ever. In a world of AI slop and sameness and customers who don‚Äôt actually believe your claims in marketing - you need a strong POV and great storytelling. Led by a human.

I‚Äôm excited to share an important update about the leadership structure at Exit Five.

After two years running our business as COO, I‚Äôve promoted Dan Murphy to CEO. 

My role as Founder & Owner does not change; more on that in a bit. 

This promotion isn‚Äôt a shift in how we operate ‚Äî it‚Äôs a recognition of the role Dan already plays in our business and a critical step in preparing us to scale and maximize our potential in the years ahead.

In the book Traction they talk about the ideal pairing between the Visionary (Founder) and the Integrator (Operator).

That describes the partnership Dan and I have well:

‚Ä¢ Visionaries are creative, strategic, restless, full of ideas, often bald - and honestly a bit dangerous without the right counterpart. They are known to start fires and run.

‚Ä¢ Integrators bring structure and process. They turn chaos into clarity. They run the business, manage teams, keep the trains moving, and allow the Visionary to focus where they are most valuable. That‚Äôs exactly what Dan has done since joining two years ago.

Dan has pushed me. He challenges every late night and weekend idea. He puts out the fires that I start. He sweats every dollar we spend. And he has consistently held a higher bar for what this company can be. Even if it's sometimes annoying and I want to yell at him :) That's what we need. That's the partner you want.

Exit Five has gone from ‚ÄúDave‚Äôs cute little solo business‚Äù to a real company with real scale because of the structure, stability, and leadership he has brought to us.

His growth over the last two years ‚Äî from VP Marketing in his last job to a true operator today ‚Äî has been incredible to watch.

Like in baseball free agency, you get paid for the job you've already done. So this title as CEO reflects who Dan has become and what our company needs for the future. 

We have big plans for 2026, 2027, and beyond. 

I am working harder on this than I have on anything in a while and having the most fun of my career.  Splitting up the CEO and Founder roles will make us all more successful for the future.

My superpowers are vision, content, product, and strategy. Working on copy, hooks, headlines, positioning, storytelling, and training our team to do the same. 

The best role for me at Exit Five is to be editor-in-chief and raise the bar on our ideas, our content, products, and the way we show up in the market. That‚Äôs where I can create the most value.

This move gives us the foundation we need for a more ambitious Exit Five ‚Äî one with more impact, more innovation, and more opportunity for our team.

Please join me in congratulating Dan on a well-earned promotion to CEO of Exit Five. 

This is an amazing milestone for our little business, and I can‚Äôt wait to see where we go from here.

NOTE: He started wearing the fanny pack before becoming CEO. But that's how I knew it was meant to be.

Also, this means I am now in full-time #FounderMode for those keeping score at home.

Congrats Dan!

If you only read one post about marketing this week it should be this one.

We are drowning in AI slop.

But I am going to throw you a life jacket.

ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude, Perplexity, this agent or that. It's all great. But here's what you really need to know about the craft of marketing.

‚Ä¢ People do not care about your company.
‚Ä¢ They don't care about your product and your features.
‚Ä¢ They don't care about the new integration you just shipped.

What they care about is themselves. 

We are biologically wired to be selfish.

So: if you can talk to someone about themselves, you‚Äôll have their full attention.

Focus on helping them first.

What is the selfish benefit to them? Why should they care?

Here are five timeless principles you can think about for your customers:

1. Make Me Look Good

Whether it‚Äôs to a boss, their team, or their industry, people are wired to care about status. Can you help them impress someone? Can you give them an edge? Can they copy/paste your idea and look smart in the next meeting? I remember impressing my boss when I was 23 year old marketer being asked to build a marketing plan for a product launch for the first time. I had no idea what to do, found a great resource from HubSpot blog (the OG) and used it. She was impressed.

2. Save Me Time

Time is the one thing nobody has enough of. If you can help someone do something faster, with less friction or fewer steps, that's the way. People will pay for time savings. BUT they have to believe this. Can't just be a marketing claim. You need proof. Show the receipts. The examples.

3. Make Me Money

Capitalism seems to be the best system that exists in the world. I don't make the rules I am just observing. It doesn't seem like someone has created a better way, so yes - money matters. And whether they will admit it or not, your customers want to make more money (because they are people). Whether directly or indirectly, people are tuned in to ROI. If you can help someone drive revenue, get more leads, reduce churn, or land a raise then you‚Äôve got their attention. Again though: MUST BE BELIEVABLE. So you must have PROOF.

4. Help Me Avoid Pain

We are wired to avoid pain. We'd almost always rather avoid pain than get some type of gain. No one likes to look stupid, feel behind, or get in trouble. If you can speak to something they‚Äôre secretly worried about -- a mistake, a missed goal, a clunky process -- and show a way out, they‚Äôll lean in.

5. Help Me Reach The Next Level

Great marketing often speaks to ambition. Career growth. Mastery. Confidence. People want to feel like they‚Äôre getting better ‚Äî at their job, in their life, as a person.

***

There's a lot of noise in marketing right now because of tech/AI, but I'm more bullish than ever on understanding the timeless principles in marketing, and that starts with understanding people.

I hope these are helpful for whatever you're working on right now.

Please don't get mad about this, but here's the truth I've learned: you get freed up to do great marketing when you are not under constant pressure to deliver a direct response on everything you do.

When every activity is not measured by the exact ROI of that activity... you are actually able to do good marketing.

You'll be able to do things that stand out, generate awareness, capture attention, build trust, create loyalty, and maybe for once actually get people sharing things about your brand.

Word of mouth is the most powerful thing a brand could have. But you don't get it when ringing the cash register is the desired outcome from every brand touch point.

OK, but how? 

Everyone always wants to know how. 

Because inside of the company, the CFO wants to know how much everything costs. The VP Sales is on your ass about the leads. The CEO is standing up in front of the board next week and she needs to show growth.

You have to educate people on how good marketing works.

I have a ton of product ideas; but I have no idea how design and engineering work. 

So they have to explain that stuff to me.

Same is true in marketing. I believe it is a true skill, a craft. And when deployed properly, it's a strategic growth lever for the business.

Is it not worth having a strong POV on what great marketing looks like? 

To teach your company, to earn the trust of the CEO, CFO, VP Sales, board, internal teams? 

You must be able to articulate what good looks like and why marketing is not just direct response.

Now of course the dream scenario is you find out the CEO gets marketing before you join the company and you don't have to do as much of this ... but you might not always be in that position (or have control to get that information, or know it's real, etc.)

But if you didn't think part of the job in marketing was to educate people on how good marketing works; then it might be better to switch careers and become an engineer, show up to work at 10 AM and code silently in the dark until 7 PM and go home. 

OK that little paragraph was unnecessary. Literally no reason for engineers to catch strays from my LinkedIn post on this fine Thursday.

But anyway... my point is this:

Internal marketing is the most underrated marketing channel; I did not make this rule. 

I am just giving you my observations from my career. 

I'm still doing calls weekly with CEOs and Founders advocating for marketing; they still need education.

It's part of the job.

How do you educate your peers about how marketing works? Not in a patronizing way, but explaining how customers get information, how they buy, why the long game matters?

Their color.

Their fur. The claws. The way they pooped indoors in a bin (still weird).

And they won me over!

They melted my cold grey heart and at the same time:

My allergies magically disappeared.

And now here I am, confessing my love for cats to the 180,000 people that follow me on LinkedIn.

What a gift!

Remote work requires an incredible amount of discipline. Not for everyone.

I think that the "back to the office" crowd often has a narrative that remote work is easier.

That remote workers are slacking off while the "real professionals" are grinding it out in the office.

But I think there's another angle to this:

Working from home exposes everything. No boss watching over your shoulder. No colleague pressure. No artificial energy from office chaos. Heck, you could be ripping the vape pen all day at work if you wanted to.

Remote work makes it more about the results (and I like that, btw)

You can't hide behind being the office social butterfly who everyone loves but whose output is average. Maybe you're fun, funny, amazing to get a coffee with - but not actually doing any real work??

Remote you can't mask weak skills with great small talk or being the person who always organizes the lunch order. But he's so nice! So fun to be around! 

Well as it turns out Todd sucks at his job...

Remote work kills the performance theater, which was always one of my biggest beefs of office culture.

Don't get me wrong - there's value in being together. I feel it every time we get our team together and there are times that I wish we all DID work together in an office.

But let's be honest about what also happens in offices: 

‚Ä¢ People spending three hours looking busy instead of productive. 
‚Ä¢ People hang around the office until a certain time vs going home when the work is done for the day
‚Ä¢ People getting promoted (or hanging around at a company longer than they should) because they're likable, not because they are delivering results.

The truth? Both can work. But they demand different skills.

Remote rewards discipline. Focus. I need to take a shower and put on real clothes to remind myself that this is work - even though it's remote.

I don't think the remote work is for everyone.

Happy (official) two year Exit Five anniversary to my guy and our COO Dan Murphy.

In the book Traction and the EOS framework, they talk about the ideal leadership pairing between the Visionary (founder) and an Integrator (the operator).

That framework is exactly what makes Dan and I work so well together.

Most entrepreneurs fall into the Visionary category: creative, strategic, restless (yep), starting fires everywhere (can confirm), big on ideas, lower on follow-through (my bad).

Integrators:

- Bring structure
- Turn chaos into clarity
- Run the business
- Manage teams
- Keep the trains running on time
- Free the Visionary to do Visionary things

Candidly, Dan can be a complete pain in my ass - but that is exactly what I need. 

Dan pushes me. He sweats every dollar we spend. He questions every late night idea we have. He has even mastered the art of putting out every fire that I start.

This is the the reason Exit Five has become a real business, a real company, and something that has already outgrown my name. It's also a profitable growth machine that is making a real impact on thousands of people around the world (I have the receipts in my Apple Notes; the impact goes well beyond B2B marketing).

Dan will tackle any problem, big or small. He's on calls with my accountant, talking to our lawyer, he's interviewing candidates, he's fixing landing pages, he's coding, he's asking me why I spent $25 on a Jimmy John's sandwich at the airport. 

But more importantly he knows what we *can* be and pushes me to raise the bar. Have a high f-ing bar is one of our core values now.

Before this I used to brag about how little I was working, and now I know why: I did not have a clear purpose. I was alone. 

That has all changed in the last two years and I can confidently say that I'm in the prime of my career and we have a great business with product market fit because this guy took my call two years ago. 

His comp was heavily weighted on performance in that first year too. He took a bet on himself, smashed the goals (turns out we're both competitive) and it's be game on ever since.

He's also a good person (imagine that!) A great Dad. Husband. And the guy I would call in a pinch, for anything.

He's also grown - big time. Maturing. Evolving from a VP Marketing to a true COO. And I know there's more to come. 

Thanks for 2 great years Dan. I hope we don't have a public falling out one day where we're talking shit about each other on Twitter!!! <3

Please go follow him on LinkedIn if you are not already.

PS. We celebrated by playing TPC Scottsdale two weeks ago after the E5 team offsite and had a blast. I think it was $500 per person for 18 holes, but we put it on the Ramp card because it's a write off!

Also: I know someone will ask "where can I find my Dan?" Well - I didnt find him on Indeed ("no offense" as my 8 year old says). I found him because we worked together for 8 years at two companies. That was the secret.

Some companies are in super regulated industries. Some have fewer rules.

But this is what's FUN. There is no formula. It's always different. Channels that worked for one company don't work for another.

This is the craft of marketing.

"Put me anywhere on God's Green Earth, I could triple my worth." - Jay-Z

That is how great marketers think too.

Any company, any stage, any industry - they could figure it out.

Wrapping up the last few days of 2025.

I love my job; I love our company. And I'm also excited to chill out for bit and come back ready to go again in January. Both things can be true!

Some notes:

‚û°Ô∏è We doubled in revenue again this year; third year in a row we have doubled. Double-double-double. Not bad.

‚û°Ô∏è Added three new teammates. It's almost always a "Who not Now" problem now. People continue to be the most important thing to get right.

‚û°Ô∏è Got on a bunch of flights; did events in five major cities. Totally worth it. In-person is much different than online in the best way. Also gives me hope for humanity. We are better to each other in-person.

‚û°Ô∏è Big sigh. Made a bunch of mistakes of course. Wasted time and money. Burnt some social capital. Hurt some feelings. Inevitable. But still sucks. I tell myself that nothing bothers me but of course that's a lie. And I know there will only be more of it if the growth curve of success continues to accelerate. Also: business is just hard. You're doing business with people. People are complicated. So it's hard to chalk it up to "it's just business."

‚û°Ô∏è Much more positive note: realized that community is an incredible moat right now. Super bullish on the future with Exit Five and professional networks/community businesses. Feel very fortunate to be in the business we're in right now. Also the brand name, awareness, and recognition shift over the last year has been real. It feels different. In the best way.

‚û°Ô∏è Still bootstrapped, no outside funding, and profitable. And just went double-double-double. Who's mad at that?

All around just having a good time too; was saying to Dan (E5 CEO) the other night on the phone -- I never got my MBA. But the amount we're learning about business through building Exit Five has been a completely unexpected benefit.  The fact that we get to make money from the business is a bonus.

OK that's not completely true; I don't have a trust fund unfortunately so I *do* need to make money through work. But my point is that we are learning so much beyond what we knew about marketing and it's super rewarding.

Content marketers run modern marketing.

Because almost all marketing today is shaped online.

And online marketing shows up as:

- Ads
- Videos
- Articles
- Podcasts and clips like this with Jess Cook
- Social posts
- Newsletters
- Communities
- Influencers

Different formats. But none of it works without a clear content strategy and strong content marketing.

Jess is a great example of this: she started her career as a copywriter for big CPG brands. She cut her teeth writing 200+ variations of a recipe for Rice Krispie Treats.

Then built a career in content marketing: content market manager, director, VP brand and content.

Then turned that into a Head of Marketing role at a startup and was recently promoted to VP on the heels of her success using - wait for it - content to drive revenue.

Not because Vector's content gets a lot of impressions and their podcast is unique or because their little mascot is cute.

But because it's working! Those things are driving revenue. 

I had a conversation with Jess last week (now out on my podcast) and she shared three key marketing plays that she's run over the past year:

1. Influencer Marketing - how does it work in B2B, how did she find influencers, what did it cost, how much pipeline was generated, how did they measure it

2. Podcasting - why they started a podcast, how their podcast stands out, how they record, when/where, how they prep, how they know it's working

3. LinkedIn - we talk a bit about what content types (and strategy) is working well here today

4. Career Path - her path from content to VP Marketing

Erin on my team messaged me last night and said this was the best interview we've done recently - please go listen if you need some tactical inspiration.
